content.webTitle: Super League’s falling giants Leeds Rhinos have that sinking feeling | Aaron Bower

fields.headline: Super League’s falling giants Leeds Rhinos have that sinking feeling
fields.bodyText: In 1974 Manchester United – six years on from winning the European Cup – were said to be too good to go down, a statement of hubris that turned out to be wildly wrongheaded. Folk from Leeds and Manchester are not too fond of being compared but 45 years on, across the other side of the Pennines, another sporting dynasty is likewise in grave danger of enduring the unthinkable. Leeds Rhinos, Super League champions eight times in 14 seasons between 2004 and 2017, are bottom of the table with 10 games remaining and at serious risk of relegation. “We’ve got a 10‑game shootout with a number of other teams,” admits their interim coach, Richard Agar. How has it come to this for the most successful club of the game’s summer era? The similarities between the Rhinos of today and that relegated United side are startling, and they begin at the top. After Matt Busby’s 24-year reign as manager ended in 1969, United went through four managers in the years leading to relegation. Leeds, coached by only three men throughout their golden era, have had more head coaches than that in the past year alone, culminating in Agar’s appointment following the dismissal of Dave Furner earlier this year. A high turnover of players, coupled with below-par recruitment, has also contributed to Leeds’ decline. “It hasn’t been good enough since Kevin Sinfield and Jamie Peacock left after the treble success of 2015,” says Peter Smith, the Yorkshire Evening Post’s rugby league correspondent for almost two decades. “While their rivals have strengthened, Leeds have relied on project signings and youngsters with limited success. The 2017 Grand Final papered over the cracks.” Sinfield now heads up Leeds’s rugby operation, having returned last year, but it is the players who have left Leeds, as well as the ones who have arrived, that make their predicament all the more painful. The Rhinos dropped to the bottom of the table after Hull KR’s victory against Hull FC. That winning Rovers team included three players who won the Grand Final with Leeds two years ago, including Matt Parcell, the hooker who scored the winning try on Thursday having been allowed to leave Leeds on loan 48 hours earlier. The Parcell move is part of a desperate attempt by Leeds to yet again refresh their squad. A cash‑plus-player deal has led to the arrival of Robert Lui from Salford, while Shaun Lunt, a Grand Final winner with Leeds in 2012, has swapped clubs with Parcell. Both will make their debuts on Sunday against Catalans. That Lui will wear the No 40 shirt underlines the lack of consistency at a once-dominant club. “I’ve got a job to do but I can’t do it by myself: it’s going to take the whole team,” says Lui. Fortunately for Leeds, perhaps, the bottom seven teams are split by only six points, making any sort of upturn in form in the final 10 weeks enough to secure survival. Leeds’ problems are, however, far more deep-rooted. The England coach, Wayne Bennett, an RFL employee, inexplicably turned up at a Rhinos training session last week to offer guidance. That has caused friction among the sides in the relegation dog fight. Of course, it was said in 1974 that relegation was the best thing to happen to United, a catalyst for brighter times. Nonetheless Rhinos supporters will certainly hope they are not wishing for the same outcome in 10 games’ time.
